items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.54mAOD at 16:30 on 09/09/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 4 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:30 on 09/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening.   

High water on Tuesday at Plymouth is at 19:53 with flooding possible between 19:00 and 21:00. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Locations particularly at risk include exposed coastal areas of Plymouth Sound including Cawsand, Kingsand and The Hoe. 

Waterside locations and roads along the estuary may be flooded.  Do not walk or drive through flood water.   

Coastal conditions should ease for Wednesday morning's high tide, however, conditions are forecast to worsen again for Wednesday evenings tide, bringing a further risk of flooding.  

We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth on Tuesday is 2.95 mAOD.  Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level.  Force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Dorset coast at Poole Harbour

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle at 10:30 PM on 09/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday.
High water at Plymouth on Tuesday is at 19:53 and Wednesday at 08:15. Flooding is possible an hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas of Fowey including Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park, Lostwithiel including Quay Street and the Recreation ground, East Looe and West Looe, Millendreath, Polperro Harbour, and the B3247 at Seaton.
Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves. 
Coastal conditions will worsen again for both high tides on Wednesday, bringing a further risk of flooding. A flood warning is also in force. 
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth on Tuesday is 2.95 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening.
High water on Tuesday at Falmouth is at 19:14 with flooding possible between 18:00 and 20:30. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Coastal conditions should ease for Wednesday morning's high tide. Conditions will worsen again for Wednesday evenings tide, bringing a further risk of flooding. A flood warning is also in force.
Locations at risk may include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn Commercial road, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Pandora Inn at Restronguet, the A390 at Tresillian. 
Low lying land, roads, car parks, harbours and quays are expected to flood. Do not walk or drive through flood water.
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Falmouth on Tuesday is 2.83 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level.  Force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
First forecast high-water is 9:30 PM on 09/09/25 with a level of 7.67 mAOD and a Force 4 Southerly wind and second forecast high-water is 9:45 AM on 10/09/25 with a level of 7.53 mAOD and a Force 4 South-westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
Further flooding is possible at high-water until Thursday due to higher than normal tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will be closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 10:30 PM on 09/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon, 09/09/2025. 
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide, but flooding is still possible at low lying lands and roads from 1:45 PM on 09/09/2025 at the following locations: 
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 2:15 PM 
Eastford Road, peaking around 2:30 PM 
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 2:45 PM 
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 10/09/2025. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 09/09/2025, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
The high tide this afternoon, Tuesday the 9th of September, is one in a sequence of high spring tides. Although the tide will be lower than last nights tide there is still the possibility of flooding to low level land and roads. Flooding is possible between 10am and 12pm with the tide peaking at approximately 11am. 
This evenings high tide will be larger as we move towards the peak tide on Wednesday evening. Flooding of properties is not expected.
Areas most at risk are within the Sandside and Arnside area of North Morecambe Bay.
Please avoid driving through flood water and do not put yourself or others at risk.
We will update this message by 3pm on Tuesday 9 September 2025, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides around 01:21AM tonight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 01:21AM on 10/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast.

Further flooding is possible tomorrow due to higher than normal tides at 01:45PM 10/09/2025 and 02:01AM 11/09/25.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible around the high tide between 11:21 PM 09/09/2025 and 3:21 AM on 10/09/2025.

We do not expect the following high tide tomorrow around 01:45PM 10/09/2025 to reach Flood Alert levels but the following nights tide will.

Areas most at risk include Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds.  The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  We will monitor the situation closely.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message: The tides have now passed and no further flooding is expected. Unsettled weather conditions are expected for the next few days so this alert may be re-issued if required.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
The threat of flooding from this morning's high tide has now passed, however water levels on the Tyne Estuary tomorrow morning, Wednesday 10/09/2025, will be higher than normal due to the high tide. 

Flooding is possible at riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads between 04:45 AM and 6:00 AM on 10/09/2025, however conditions can apply for two to four hours on either side of a high tide. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue the flood alert for future tides if required. 

Please be careful along riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Lands End to Lizard Point
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening.   
High water on Tuesday at Newlyn is at 18:42 with flooding possible between 18:00 and 20:00. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas around Penzance Harbour, including Abbey Slip and Wharf Road car park, Newlyn harbour, Marazion (Green Lane area), Porthleven Harbour, and Mullion Cove. 
Waves and spray are likely so take care near the coast. Do not walk or drive through flood water or waves.   
Coastal conditions should ease for Wednesday morning's high tide, however, conditions are forecast to worsen again for Wednesday evenings tide, bringing a further risk of flooding.
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by midday on Wednesday, or if the situation changes.   
Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 3.17 mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Force 3 southwesterly winds and offshore wave heights of around 2.7m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:30pm and 2:30pm today, Tuesday 9th September.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.83 mAODN at 1:30pm on Tuesday 9th September, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 1, Easterly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th September.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: High spring tides means that high tides are expected between 5:30 am and 10 am tomorrow morning, 10/09/2025.  Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.72 mAODN 7:45am, on Wednesday 10 September, which is 0.01m above tide tables, wind Force 5, SE. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).   Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 10 September.

items.message: High spring tides means that high tides are expected between 5:30 am and 10 am tomorrow morning, 10/09/2025.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.72 mAODN 7:45am, on Wednesday 10 September, which is 0.01m above tide tables, wind Force 5, SE. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).   Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 10 September.

High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Highest tide level is expected to be at West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit at 7:45 PM on 09/09/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.
We will remove this message by 10:00 AM on 10/09/2025.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a result of an ongoing period of high tides. Tides will be at their highest between 20:45 on 08/09/25 and 21:45 Wednesday, 10/09/25. Flooding to roads and low lying land adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the times of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides.
Predicted peaks at Newport 7.5m at 21:15 on 09/09 and 7.4m at 09:30 on 10/09.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 13:00 on 10/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Trent for riverside areas from Gainsborough to the Humber confluence

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby River gauge as a result of high spring tides.  Flooding is possible on high tides this evening between 7pm and 9pm on 09/09/2025, and between 7am and 9am tomorrow morning, 10/09/2025.  Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and Neap House road.
   
We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday (11/09/2025).
We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 10/09/2025, or as the situation changes.
